title: 111_s2885
content: The "First Responders Support Act of 2009" is the short title of this Act. It aims to expand disability benefits for first responders. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to increase the benefit amount to $350,000 and expedite the process for determining eligibility. The Attorney General is required to establish regulations within 9 months of the Act's enactment. The Attorney General will promulgate regulations to implement the amendments made by the Act. Authorization of appropriations includes funding for hiring employees, obtaining technology and equipment, educating and assisting eligible agencies, providing supplemental materials for continuing education, and supporting public safety officers and first responders in rural areas. The Attorney General will promulgate regulations to implement the amendments made by the Act, including funding for supporting public safety officers and first responders in rural and urban areas with a population of less than 25,000. SEC. 3. EDUCATIONAL BENEFITS. Section 1212(a) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to provide financial assistance to eligible dependents at a monthly rate of up to $1,500, based on their academic workload. The Director will establish regulations for this assistance annually. The First Responders Support Act of 2009 allows for adjustments to the benefit level based on the Consumer Price Index. Eligible dependents will receive financial assistance up to $1,500 per month, based on their academic workload. SEC. 4. PRIORITIZATION OF CLAIMS. The Bureau will prioritize claims based on severity and likelihood of approval, giving priority to death benefits or 100 percent disability claims. SEC. 5. EXPANDING COUNSELING AND MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES. In this section, the term "Director" refers to the Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance. An "eligible organization" provides free or reduced cost mental health services to public safety officers injured in the line of duty. A "public safety officer" is defined in section 1204 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. "Reduced cost" means charging no more than 50 percent of the usual fee for mental health services. The Director can grant funds to eligible organizations for providing mental health services to injured public safety officers and their families. Eligible organizations must apply for grants following the Director's guidelines. The Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance will implement a performance measure for the Public Safety Officers Benefits program to monitor claims and benefits. They will also report annually to Congress on program performance, technological updates, payment status, and outreach activities.
